channel.title: History Future Now
channel.description: Data-driven analysis of the structural forces — demographic, technological, economic — that will shape the next century.

item.title: The Invisible Judge: Why Guilt and Shame Societies Are Incompatible
item.description: Guilt societies are ruled by an internal judge; shame societies by the eye of the crowd. The difference shapes corruption, rule of law, and how civilisations understand each other — when they meet, they often don't recognise the same rules.

item.title: What Worked: Five Thousand Years of Evidence for How Civilisations Flourish
item.description: Most political positions are argued from ideology. History Future Now's are argued from evidence. Five thousand years of civilisational data — from Sumer to Singapore — points consistently in the same direction. These are not opinions. They are observations. And they are a blueprint for the future.

item.title: When the Servants Are Silicon: What History's Leisure Classes Reveal About the AI Age
item.description: Robots are not stealing jobs. They are replacing the unborn. When the Shadow Workforce handles survival, eight billion people become an aristocracy. Athens used that freedom to invent philosophy. Rome used it to invent gladiators. Which will we choose?

item.title: The Atom Returns: Why the World's Most Feared Energy Source Is Its Best Hope
item.description: Microsoft signed a deal to restart Three Mile Island for AI power. France generates 70% of its electricity from nuclear at half Germany's carbon intensity. China is building 150 reactors. The atom is back — and the nations that embrace it will thrive.

item.title: The Debasement: Why Every Great Power That Borrowed Its Way to Greatness Borrowed Its Way to Ruin
item.description: The US spent more on interest payments than on defence in 2025 for the first time in history. Spain defaulted six times between 1557 and 1647. France's debt triggered the Revolution. The pattern is always the same.

item.title: The Great Divergence: Why Young Men and Women No Longer See the Same World
item.description: Young women have moved sharply more liberal across the developed world. Young men have not — or have moved more conservative. The gap is historically unprecedented. The political and demographic consequences will be profound.

item.title: The Last Drop: Why Every Civilisation That Ran Out of Water Collapsed
item.description: Water is the one resource for which there is no substitute. Every major civilisation was built on water management — Mesopotamia's canals, Egypt's Nile, Rome's aqueducts. And every civilisation that lost control of its water supply collapsed. The modern world is running dry.

item.title: The Locked Gate: How the West Priced Its Children Out of Existence
item.description: The average house in England costs 7.7 times the median salary. In Seoul, a young couple saves for 18 years to buy a flat. Every city with extreme housing costs has a fertility rate below 1.5. This is not coincidence. It is causation.

item.title: The New Oil: Why the Race for Critical Minerals Will Define the 21st Century
item.description: China banned gallium and germanium exports in 2023 and most Western policymakers had never heard of either element. The energy transition depends on minerals most people cannot name, mined in places most people cannot find on a map, and processed in one country.

item.title: A Nation Transformed: Britain's Demographic Revolution, 1948–2050
item.description: Britain has undergone one of the most rapid peacetime demographic transformations in European history. It was not planned. It emerged from a sequence of policy decisions — and its long-term trajectory is one of the most significant and least-discussed facts about Britain's future.

item.title: The Great Offshoring: How the World's Factory Moved East
item.description: In a single generation, the West gave away the industrial monopoly it had held for two centuries. From the rust belts of the Midlands to the boomtowns of Guangdong, this is the story of the Great Offshoring — told through the data that reveals who won.

item.title: The Builders Are Dying: How the Populations That Made the Modern World Are Disappearing — And What Happens Next
item.description: Between them, European and East Asian civilisations built virtually everything that defines the modern world — the scientific method, industrial manufacturing, semiconductors, the internet, modern medicine. Both populations are now in demographic freefall. The question nobody wants to ask: who maintains the world after the builders are gone?

item.title: The Gates of Nations: How Every Civilisation in History Controlled Immigration — Until the West Stopped
item.description: For five thousand years, every successful civilisation tightly controlled who could enter, settle, and become a citizen. Then, in the space of a single generation, the West decided this was bigotry. The historical record suggests the experiment will not end well.

item.title: The New Literacy: How AI Is Killing The Scribes And What Happens Next
item.description: For five thousand years, if you could not write, you hired a scribe. If you could not code, you hired a developer. AI has just made everyone literate in the digital scribal arts — coding, design, filmmaking, marketing — in months, not decades. The middlemen are disappearing and a flourishing has begun. But history shows what comes after the flourishing: dependency and atrophy. The question is how long the golden age lasts.

item.title: Europe Rearms: Why The Continent That Invented Total War Is Spending €800 Billion On Defence
item.description: In 1932, Germany spent less than 1% of GDP on its military. By 1939, that figure was 23%. The transformation took just seven years. Today, Europe is embarking on the fastest rearmament since the Cold War. History suggests that once the machine starts, it is very hard to stop.

item.title: The Death Of The Fourth Estate: What The Collapse Of Newspapers Means For Democracy, Power, And Truth
item.description: On February 4th 2026, a Washington Post reporter in a warzone in Ukraine learned by text message that she had been laid off. Nearly half the newsroom was gone in a single day. This is not just a story about one newspaper. Every revolution in information technology has overthrown the existing power structure. Every single one.

item.title: The Return of the State Factory: Why Nations That Forgot How To Make Things Are Remembering
item.description: In February 2026, the United States signed a trade deal with Taiwan that included $250 billion in semiconductor investment pledges. Tariffs are back. Industrial policy is back. After forty years of being told that manufacturing didn't matter, every serious nation on Earth is scrambling to rebuild its factories. History explains why — and what comes next.

item.title: Who Guards The Guards? Bureaucracy, Empire, And The Eternal Struggle To Control The State
item.description: Elon Musk's DOGE initiative has identified $215 billion in US government savings and aims for $2 trillion. The EU's regulatory apparatus grows by thousands of pages each year. Every civilisation in history has faced the same problem: the people hired to run the state eventually capture it. The question is whether AI can break the pattern.

item.title: The Scramble For The Solar System: Why The Next Colonial Race Has Already Begun
item.description: SpaceX is building Starship production lines at scale. China plans a permanent lunar base by 2030. NASA's Artemis programme aims to return Americans to the Moon. India, Japan, and the UAE have all sent missions to the Moon or Mars. The Outer Space Treaty of 1967 says nobody can claim territory in space. History says that treaty will be ignored — just like every other treaty that stood between great powers and unclaimed resources.

item.title: The Silence Of The Scribes: How Every Civilisation That Controlled Speech Collapsed
item.description: In February 2026, India ordered social media platforms to remove content within three hours of a government request. The EU's Digital Services Act empowers bureaucrats to police online speech across 27 nations. Meanwhile, Elon Musk is fighting to make X a global free speech platform. The battle over who controls information is the oldest power struggle in human history. Every civilisation that chose censorship over openness eventually fell behind — and fell apart.
